entry.title: SAP Document AI accelerates document-centric business processes with Generative AI
entry.content:
Authors: @amagnani37 & @merza 

Thank you to everyone who joined our recent partner webinar, "Streamline document processing with SAP Document AI". This session was part of our ongoing partner webinar series, "Talk to your business with Generative AI", and the turnout and engagement were fantastic.

For those who couldn't make it, or for anyone who wants a recap, weâ€”Merza Klaghstan, Alice Magnani, and Jacob Tan from the BTP & AI Solution Architects team â€”wanted to share the key takeaways, demos, and technical insights from the session.

Our goal was to go beyond a simple feature list and show you how SAP Document AI can be the centerpiece of a complete, end-to-end business solution.

Hereâ€™s what we covered.

Part 1: What is SAP Document AI and Why Does it Matter?

We kicked off by tackling the core business problem: a staggering 70-80% of all enterprise information is unstructured. Manually processing this data from documents, emails, and scans is not only slow but also expensive and prone to errors.

SAP Document AI, formerly known as Document Information Extraction (DOX), is SAP's AI-powered solution on the Business Technology Platform (BTP) designed to solve this. It goes far beyond simple Optical Character Recognition (OCR) to extract, classify, and validate data with high precision.

Key Capabilities

We highlighted several key features:

  • Multiple Editions: The service is available in Base AI, Premium AI (which includes Generative AI capabilities), and Embedded editions to fit different use cases. We also want to highlight for our SAP Partners that the Premium AI edition is part of the Test, Demo, and Development (TDD) license, which provides a much more convenient model for your non-productive and internal development purposes.

     

  • The New "Workspace" UI: We compared the classic "Basic" UI with the new, full-featured "Workspace," which is the future of the service and includes capabilities like email channel configuration and workflow management.

    It's the new, full-featured environment for all document processing tasks . We want to emphasize that from now on, all the latest SAP Document AI features will be available in the Workspace UI only, so we strongly advise using it for all new projects.

     

  • Pre-Configured & Custom Content (Schemas): The service provides many pre-trained models (called "Schemas") for standard documents like invoices and purchase orders. The real power, however, comes from creating custom schemas for any document type your business needsâ€”from specialized licenses to internal forms.

     

  • Generative AI & Instant Learning: For custom schemas, SAP Document AI leverages Generative AI and Large Language Models (LLMs) to understand and extract information. We also demonstrated "Instant Learning," where the model learns from your manual corrections immediately. After one correction, it knows how to handle that document layout correctly the next time.

    In our demo, we showed how the model initially struggled with a name containing a middle name and extracted the wrong federation name (full name vs. acronym) . After one manual correction and confirmation, it learned immediately. Technically, this feature uses few-shots prompting to make the underlying LLM aware of your previously reviewed documents to improve accuracy on the next run.

Part 2: A Real-World Use Case: "Vertigo Travels"

To make this real, we introduced "Vertigo Travels," a fictional travel agency specializing in sports and adventure holidays. Their key challenge is managing the various kind of documents required for subscriptions, such as ID cards, medical certificates, and diving licenses.

The solution architecture includes:

  1. The Vertigo Travels website, a frontend application,  deployed in Cloud Foundry, serving as entry point for Travelers to select travel packages and upload the necessary documents, such as ID cards or medical certificates. The backend logic is a CAP (Node.js) application also deployed in a cloud Foundry.

  2. SAP Document AI, for all document intelligence operations, communicating via API with our backend application.

  3. SAP HANA Cloud, as a persistence layer for our application, to store all the entities involved in the subscription process.

  4. SAP Build Work Zone standard edition, as the entry point for Vertigo Travels employees to supervise the process. From Work Zone, business users can access the Vertigo Travel website for admin operations, or the SAP Document AI workspace, for instance to review documents. SAP Build Work Zone also allows business users to use SAP Document AI via mobile.

  5. SAP Build Process Automation, to define business rules to automate some document validation checks. Although this could also be implemented as part of the  Vertigo Travels backend application, SAP Build Process Automation enables citizen developers to modify easily the business logics when required.

  6. SAP S/4HANA Cloud, as the core SAP Cloud solution. The Vertigo Travels backend is integrated with modules such as Business Partners, Products, Sales Orders/Invoice, Customer Return for refund.

For the source code, you may refer here for reference.

P.S. if you're planning to work on this prototype, please give us a shout out~! So at least we know somebody is trying our repository out!

We demonstrated three end-to-end scenarios:

  1. The E2E Flow: A traveler, Mary, subscribes on the website and uploads her documents. A back-office employee, Barry, reviews and corrects one document in the Document AI Workspace. Once confirmed, a Sales Order is automatically created in S/4HANA Cloud.

  2. Multi-Channel Ingestion: A traveler, Luca, visits an office. The employee uses SAP Mobile Start to scan his ID and medical certificate. The system then automatically emails Luca about a missing document. He simply replies to the email with his license attached, which is automatically ingested via the Inbound Channel feature.

  3. Automation: A traveler, Claire, uploads an income statement to apply for a discount. SAP Build Process Automation runs a rule to check her eligibility. When she submits her final documents, they have a high confidence score and are auto-confirmed without any manual review.

Part 3: How We Built It (The Technical Deep Dive)

For our developer community, we walked through the "how-to" for the key components.

For the source code, you may refer here for reference.

P.S. if you're planning to work on this prototype, please give us a shout out~! So at least we know somebody is trying our repository out!

1. Setup and Schema Management: We started with the BTP setup, which involves managing entitlements, creating the service instance, and, critically, establishing trust with SAP Cloud Identity Service (IAS) for user authorization. We then showed how to create the custom schemas that power the application.

When you set up your entitlements, make sure to use the application subscription ending in -ias (Identity Authentication Service), as this is the one that provisions the new Workspace interface.

2. API-Driven Development: Our CAP application's backend communicates directly with Document AI's APIs. We showed code snippets for uploading a file (using the FileService) and processing it against a schema (using the SchemaService).

How to retrieve specific extracted values:
While our demo UI showed a simple text extraction, your application will likely need specific, structured data (like "gross_family_income" or "number_of_kids"). The API makes this straightforward:

    • After processing the document, you get a Document ID.
    • You can use this Document ID to retrieve the Document Version ID.
    • Using the Version ID, you can then query the Entities for that document. 4. Finally, you can retrieve the specific value by using the Entity ID (e.g., the ID for your "number_of_kids" field) .

This is how our automation process, for example, was able to pull only the family income and number of kids to pass to the rules engine.

3. Configuring Email Ingestion: We configured the "Channels" feature to monitor an email inbox. This required registering an app in Microsoft Azure, granting Mail.ReadWrite permissions , and then using the Document AI Workspace to map a specific email folder to our target schema.

4. Enabling SAP Mobile Start: This was a key integration for the in-office scenario. It involved three steps:

    • Adding the Document AI dependency to SAP Build Work Zone within the IAS console.
    • Creating a specific BTP destination (sapdocumentaimobilestartintegration).
    • Configuring the app tile in the Work Zone Site Manager with the correct navigation and visualization parameters (e.g., mobilestart.type = documentAi).

4. Automating Logic with SAP Build Process Automation: To keep our application logic flexible, we externalized our validation rules. We created a process in SAP Build Process Automation with a Decision Table (Rule) to calculate the family discount based on income and number of kids. This process is exposed as an API and triggered by our CAP application.

For the source code, you may refer here for reference.

P.S. if you're planning to work on this prototype, please give us a shout out~! So at least we know somebody is trying our repository out!

Part 4: Conclusion, Best Practices, and What's Next

We concluded with some key advice and a look ahead.

Best Practices & Responsible AI

  • Quality In, Quality Out: The accuracy of extraction heavily depends on the quality of your scans.
  • Human in the Loop: While automation is powerful, always design your processes with a "human in the loop" for validation, especially for critical data.
  • Responsible AI: We reiterated SAP's commitment to AI ethics. External LLM providers are carefully selected and are not permitted to store or retrain their models on customer data. Features like continuous data sharing for model improvement are strictly opt-in and should not be used for sensitive personal data.

Get Started and Look Ahead

We are committed to helping our partners build on this platform. Here are the resources to get you started:

  • SAP Document AI Official Help Page: https://url.sap/imohkv
  • Vertigo Travels GitHub Repository: https://url.sap/pi5vwn (The code for our demo app will be available here!)
  • SAP Community for AI/ML: https://url.sap/ai-ml-grp

The roadmap for SAP Document AI is packed with features, including more pre-built schemas, document workflows, custom LLM prompting, and deeper integration with Joule.

Finally, don't miss SAP TechEd Virtual! Be sure to check out sessions AI821v and AI102v for the latest roadmap and deep-dive innovations from the product team.

Please feel free to leave any questions or feedback in the comments below!

entry.title: New Kyma Telemetry Docs: Simplified, Task-Oriented, and User-First
entry.content:
We're happy to announce the release of the completely restructured and rewritten documentation for the Kyma Telemetry module! We've moved from a component-centric view to a user-first, task-oriented structure, all centered around a new, unified Telemetry Pipeline API.

 

What's New for Our Users?

  • The Unified Telemetry Pipeline API â€“ At the heart of the new structure is the Telemetry Pipeline API. With the introduction of OTLP-based LogPipelines, you can now use a consistent set of CRDs to configure all your telemetry signals, which reduces complexity and makes your setup easier to maintain.

  • A Clearer, Task-Based Structure â€“ Find what you need faster with new top-level guides for Collecting Logs, Collecting Traces, and Collecting Metrics. Each guide walks you through the process for a specific signal, from minimal setup to advanced configuration

  • A Clear Migration Path â€“ If you're still using the legacy Fluent Bit (HTTP) log output, read Migrate Your LogPipeline From HTTP to OTLP, which guides you step-by-step to switch to the new OTLP setup without data loss.

The 'Why' Behind the Change: A Look at the Craft

If you're a fellow tech writer or just curious about the why, this wasn't just a rewrite; it was a fundamental shift in our information architecture:

Our previous documentation was component-centric. It described each component (Telemetry Manager, gateways, agents, pipelines...) and its internal architecture, explaining "What does the component do?". Based on that, the reader had to figure out how to accomplish a task.

Our new approach is goal-oriented, built on principles from the DITA (Darwin Information Typing Architecture) and industry best practices. Our guiding question is "What is the user trying to achieve?" This led us to structure the content as self-contained pages, each focusing on a user goal. For readers interested in the nitty-gritty details - you still find all of those in the consolidated Architecture docs.

Why This Matters

This new structure makes it easier to see what's common and what's different for the Telemetry pipeline types. Furthermore, we've re-centered the documentation on the actions you need to perform:

  • Start with your goal: Task-oriented titles such as Monitor Pipeline Health help you find what you need without knowing our internal component names.
  • Progressive disclosure of information: Get started with a minimal configuration quickly, and then explore advanced operations like filtering or processing only when you need them.
  • Get straight to the point: With consolidated troubleshooting instructions on the top level, you can start start fixing issues immediately without reading through unrelated details.

Get Started Today

We invite you to dive into the new Telemetry module documentation. We're proud of this new structure and believe it's a clear step up for clarity and usability.

Your Feedback Matters

Whether you're a user of the module or a fellow writer, we'd love to hear your thoughts. Give us feedback directly on the SAP Help Portal pages. Your input is crucial as we continue to evolve our content.

entry.title: Beyond REST: Exploring GraphQL API Integration in SAP BTP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Introduction

GraphQL is transforming the way modern applications connect to and consume enterprise data, offering efficient and flexible querying  developers and integration designers. In SAP landscapes, this means you can consolidate complex integration flows and reduce payload size.

This article introduces GraphQL basics and demonstrates how to integrate SAP Cloud Integration with GraphQL APIs, delivering practical and step-by-step hands on you can apply to your own integration scenarios.

Recently I had an opportunity to work on an integration project where the customer extensively leveraged GraphQL APIs. That's where I thought sharing my experience will be helpful for developers to help in their GraphQL integration journey.

 

What is GraphQL?

Before we dive into actual integration flow, let us first try to understand some basics of GraphQL.

GraphQL is a query language for APIs that executes queries against a defined and a strongly-typed schema. Unlike traditional REST APIs that expose multiple endpoints for specific data objects, GraphQL APIs provide a single endpoint where clients can request exactly the fields they need, avoiding both over-fetching and under-fetching of data.

It is a schema based approach that gives the consumers of the APIs more control over the data retrieval at the same time making integrations more flexible, particularly in complex enterprise landscapes.

Before jumping on the GraphQL integration, first take a look at a sample GraphQL API (which I have also used in my demo)

Countries API: Explore country details such as languages, capitals, and regions.

  • Endpoint: https://countries.trevorblades.com/

  • Example Query 1: Fetch all countries.
query {
  countries {
    code
    name
    capital
    continent {
      name
    }
    languages {
      name
    }
  }
}
â€‹
  • Example Query 2: Fetch country with code
query {
  country(code:"US") {
    code
    name
    capital
    continent {
      name
    }
    languages {
      name
    }
  }
}

In the above two examples, if you see the API endpoint remains same but the query changes based on the desired response. You can add or remove attributes from the query section.

Try out by yourself and you will understand the basics quickly.

 

The Core Challenges

Unlike OData or SOAP, there isnâ€™t a native GraphQL adapter available in SAP BTP Cloud Integration. This means you canâ€™t directly select a â€œGraphQLâ€ protocol from the standard adapter list when configuring your integration flows. 

Good News: We can leverage standard HTTP adapter for this type of integration.

You must also set appropriate HTTP headers (such as Content-Type, authentication/tokens etc.). Parsing the flexible GraphQL responses often involves extra effort during mapping or transformation compared to protocol-specific adapters.

Another challenge is that as GraphQL provides flexible schema, there is often no OpenAPI or Swagger specifications available for these APIs. This makes integration highly adaptable but developers have to rely on documentation instead of OpenAPI contract like YAML file. Which means you may not be able to directly use standard message mappings directly.

Good News: We can leverage converters (JSON to XML) and groovy scripting extensively to handle transformations and message processing.

 

Real World Use Case

I tackled a real-world scenario which I will explain briefly. The use case centered around synchronizing stock levels between an e-commerce platform and SAP S/4HANA.

  • Whenever the e-commerce marketplace detects an order change, it sends a notification event to the integration flow.

  • The flow receives this event and extracts the order code from the notification event.

  • Using this order code, the flow triggers a GraphQL API call to fetch up-to-date order details for that order code from the customer e-commerce platform.

  • The retrieved order information is then mapped to the corresponding SAP S/4HANA object, enabling an accurate and timely order data integrity within the ERP system.

This integration ensures both systems remain aligned and allows real-time order data synchronization based on event-based design.

To simulate this integration, I used a similar workflow, but using the countries GraphQL API to explain the integration.

 

Integration Flow Walkthrough

In this section, I will walk you through the integration flow (iFlow) to connect SAP BTP Cloud Integration with a GraphQL API. Below is a screenshot of the iFlow design, highlighting the main components involved in orchestrating the request and handling the response.

Figure-1: Integration Flow

We will break down main steps to understand:

  1. How the flow is structured
  2. How the HTTP adapter is configured
  3. How message processing and data mapping are managed for GraphQL integration
  • Groovy Scripting: Groovy gives control for creating GraphQL request. Here is a sample groovy script which I have used
import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper;
import groovy.json.JsonBuilder;

def Message processData(Message message) 
{
	def body = message.getBody(java.lang.String) as String;
	def jsonInput = new JsonSlurper().parseText(body);

	if(!jsonInput) {
		throw new IllegalArgumentException("Input payload is empty or null");
	}
	
	def countryCode = (jsonInput.countryCode != null) ? jsonInput.countryCode : "IN";

	def graphQLQuery = """query {
  		country(code: "${countryCode}") {
  		  name
  		  native
  		  capital
  		  currency
  		  languages {
  		    name
  		  }
  		}
	}""";
	
	// Convert the GraphQL query into a JSON payload and set it as message body
    def jsonBody = new JsonBuilder([query: graphQLQuery]).toString()
    message.setBody(jsonBody)
	message.setHeader("Content-Type", "application/json");

	//log message body
	def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message);
	if(messageLog != null) {
		messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("GraphQL Request Body", jsonBody, "text/plain");
	}

	return message;
}â€‹

  • HTTP Adapter: Use standard HTTP adapter to provide GraphQL API endpoint, authentication, additional headers etc. In this POC, I have skipped the authentication piece as our main focus is GraphQL API integration.

  • JSON to XML Converter: After getting the JSON response, leverage the JSON to XML converter to get the XML payload.

  • Message Mapping: Once you get the sample XML, generate an XSD using XSD generator tools. This XSD can be used as a source XSD in the message mapping component. The target XSD is the one which you can get the the target API schema (Either SOAP Or OData) 

I have provided the integration flows in my GitHub

Take time to download the package, deploy it in your tenant and give it a try.

 

Mutations

In the above integration flow, I have only shown how to get the data using GraphQL APIs. But in real world you might also be required to create or update data. The countries GraphQL API is READ ONLY but I will explain theoretically how we can accomplish it in a groovy which you can use it as reference (provided your API supports it).

Suppose I want to update capital name of any country.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
import groovy.json.JsonSlurper;
import groovy.json.JsonBuilder;

def String getGraphQLQuery() {
    return '''
    mutation UpdateCountryCapital($input: UpdateCountryInput!) {
      updateCountryCapital(input: $input) {
        code
        name
        capital
      }
    }
    '''
}

def Message processData(Message message) 
{
    def body = message.getBody(java.lang.String) as String
    def inputJson = new JsonSlurper().parseText(body)
    if (!inputJson) {
        throw new IllegalArgumentException("Input payload is empty or null");
    }
    // Compose the input for GraphQL variables
    def inputMap = [
        code: inputJson.code,
        capital: inputJson.capital
    ]

    // Build the GraphQL mutation payload
    def graphQLBody = [
        query: getGraphQLQuery(),
        variables: [input: inputMap]
    ]
    def jsonBody = new JsonBuilder(graphQLBody).toString()
    message.setBody(jsonBody)
    message.setHeader("Content-Type", "application/json");

    // Optional: log message body
    def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message);
    if(messageLog != null) {
        messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("GraphQL Request Body", jsonBody, "text/plain");
    }

    return message;
}

Note: Above groovy is an example to showcase how to build CREATE/UPDATE request for GraphQL API. 

 

Conclusion

Integrating GraphQL APIs with SAP BTP Cloud Integration opens up flexible, dynamic data exchange between external applications and your SAP landscape even without a native GraphQL adapter.

By leveraging the HTTP adapter, Groovy scripting and powerful message processing tools like JSON-to-XML conversion and custom mappings, you can successfully bridge the gap.

While GraphQLâ€™s adaptable schema presents unique integration challenges, it also enables precise and efficient data retrieval. With a clear understanding of the core concepts, tools and practical steps covered in this walkthrough, you are ready to design robust solutions for similar event-driven scenarios in your own enterprise.

entry.title: Understanding Shadow AI and Its Impact on Data Security
entry.content:
Hi community! This is my second post here, and I wanted to share a topic that keeps coming up in conversations with many IT leaders lately: Shadow AI. 

Weâ€™ve all noticed how quickly AI tools have found their way into our daily routines. It often starts with small things: someone uses ChatGPT to summarize a meeting, another person drafts a report with Gemini, or a colleague asks an AI tool to polish a sales email. Most of the time, these actions come from curiosity or a genuine wish to save time and work better. 

But sometimes, we might be introducing risk when using these tools without IT oversight. 

A recent example that caught my attention came from the legal world. Some in-house lawyers at large companies were using public AI tools to draft contracts or analyze documents. One case described a lawyer uploading confidential merger files into a personal account just to meet a deadline. It sounds extreme, but it happens more often than we think... 

Of course, people donâ€™t intend to break the rules or do something dangerous. They just want to get things done faster. Still, when you use an AI tool without reading its data policies first, you might be exposing sensitive information or allowing it to be used for unintended purposes. Once that data leaves the companyâ€™s ecosystem, no one can fully control where it goes or how itâ€™s handled. 

This is what many are calling Shadow AI. Itâ€™s the evolution of Shadow IT. Years ago, employees installed their own software or used unapproved SaaS apps to get their work done. Now, itâ€™s large language models quietly spreading across teams without IT even knowing. 

Why does it happen? Usually, as I mentioned, itâ€™s simply because people want to be more efficient. When official tools are too limited or slow, they look for alternatives that help them. 

Thatâ€™s why I believe the solution isnâ€™t to block AI, but to guide its use. When enterprises make AI available inside secure environments like SAP, people can use it safely and productively at the same time. 

Imagine a legal department using AI built into their SAP environment to review contracts or summarize long documents. The team saves time, but everything stays within the companyâ€™s governance and data protection rules. The same idea applies to finance teams running forecasts or HR teams preparing reports. 

AI can help... as long as it happens in a trusted space. 

Shadow AI isnâ€™t about people doing something wrong. Itâ€™s about people trying to do their best with the tools they have. The challenge for leaders is to give them the right environment to expermient. 

And thatâ€™s the beauty of it: SAP gives you a safe space to experiment with AI through its own suite of tools - Joule, BTP, and Datasphere. 

Thanks for reading! Iâ€™d love to know if youâ€™ve seen similar situations in your teams, or how your organization is balancing innovation and data protection.

entry.title: Send Email in SAP CAP After Deprecation of @sap-cloud-sdk/mail-client
entry.content:
ğŸš€ Introduction

If youâ€™ve recently upgraded your SAP CAP project, you might have noticed that the @SAP-cloud-sdk/mail-client package is now deprecated. This package was previously used to trigger emails from CAP applications via destinations on SAP BTP.

In this post, weâ€™ll walk through a simple yet powerful alternative using Nodemailer, a Node.js-based email library, to send formatted HTML emails directly from CAP services â€” ideal for workflows such as failure notifications, approvals, or report generation alerts.

ğŸ§± Prerequisites

  • SAP CAP Project (Node.js-based)
  • Access to a Mail Server (Destination screenshot attached)
  • Basic knowledge of Node.js modules
  • Installed dependency:
npm install nodemailer axios @sap-cloud-sdk/connectivity

âš™ï¸ Step 1: Set Up Nodemailer in CAP

Create a utility file srv/utils/mailService.js and configure your mail transporter using the destination defined in SAP BTP.

Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials

This means your mail destination uses a client ID and client secret to fetch an access token before sending mail â€” (Basic Authentication case we use username and password ).

const axios = require("axios");
const nodemailer = require("nodemailer");
const { getDestination } = require("@sap-cloud-sdk/connectivity");

async function sendEmail(mailService, to, subject, body) {
  try {
    // 1ï¸âƒ£ Fetch destination details from BTP
    const destination = await getDestination({
      destinationName: mailService.destination,
    });

    if (!destination) {
      throw new Error("Destination not found.");
    }

    // 2ï¸âƒ£ Extract required properties
    const host = destination.originalProperties.destinationConfiguration["mail.smtp.host"];
    const port = destination.originalProperties.destinationConfiguration["mail.smtp.port"];
    const user = destination.originalProperties.destinationConfiguration["mail.smtp.from"];
    const tokenUrl = destination.tokenServiceUrl;
    const clientId = destination.clientId;
    const clientSecret = destination.clientSecret;
    const scope = destination.originalProperties.destinationConfiguration["scope"];

    // 3ï¸âƒ£ Get OAuth2 access token
    const tokenResponse = await axios.post(
      tokenUrl,
      new URLSearchParams({
        client_id: clientId,
        client_secret: clientSecret,
        scope,
        grant_type: "client_credentials",
      }),
      {
        headers: { "Content-Type": "application/x-www-form-urlencoded" },
      }
    );

    const accessToken = tokenResponse.data.access_token;

    // 4ï¸âƒ£ Create transporter for SMTP with OAuth2
    const transporter = nodemailer.createTransport({
      host,
      port: Number(port),
      secure: false,
      auth: {
        type: "OAuth2",
        user,
        accessToken,
      },
      tls: {
        rejectUnauthorized: false,
      },
    });

    // 5ï¸âƒ£ Mail details
    const mailOptions = {
      from: user,
      to,
      subject,
      // text: "text message" use this when you want to send only text message
      html: body,
    };

    // 6ï¸âƒ£ Send mail
    await transporter.sendMail(mailOptions);

    console.log("âœ… Mail sent successfully");
    return "Mail sent successfully";
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("âŒ Mail send failed:", err.response?.data || err);
    throw new Error("Mail send failed: " + err.message);
  }
}

module.exports = { sendEmail };

ğŸ“© Step 2: Create a Formatted HTML Template

Hereâ€™s an HTML mail template for a simple Hello Message:

export const simpleHelloMailTemplate = (recipientName) => `
  <p>Dear ${recipientName},</p>

  <p>
    This is a <b>test email</b> sent from the <b>SAP CAP Application</b> using Nodemailer.
  </p>

  <p>
    Best Regards,<br>
    Shahrukh
  </p>
`;

ğŸ§  Step 3: Trigger Email in CAP Event or Error Handler

Now call this mail utility in your CAP event handler whenever a workflow or process fails or requires a notification:

import { sendEmail } from "./utils/mailService.js";
import { simpleHelloMailTemplate } from "./utils/mailTemplate.js";

this.on("sendEmail", async (req) => {
  try {
    const html = simpleHelloMailTemplate("SRK");

    await sendEmail(
      { destination: "mail-service-destination" }, // your destination name
      "yourEmail@sap.com",
      "Hello Mail",
      html
    );

    return "âœ… Mail sent successfully!";
  } catch (err) {
    console.error("âŒ Mail sending failed:", err);
    req.error(500, "Mail Not Sent");
  }
});

ğŸ” Step 4: Secure OAuth2 Credentials

Since this setup already uses OAuth2 Client Credentials from the BTP destination, you donâ€™t need to store or manage usernames/passwords. The client ID and client secret are securely stored within your destination configuration on BTP, and tokens are fetched dynamically at runtime.

Attached Destination screenshot for reference

âœ… No manual secret management required! Just make sure your CAP application is bound to the destination service instance so it can fetch credentials using the SAP Connectivity service.

ğŸŒŸ Result

Once implemented, youâ€™ll receive a well-formatted email notification like this:

Subject: Hello Mail

Dear SRK,
This is a test email sent from the SAP CAP Application using Nodemailer.
Best Regards,
Shahrukh

If youâ€™ve received this message, your mail configuration is working perfectly! ğŸ‰

ğŸ§© Key Takeaways

  • @SAP-cloud-sdk/mail-client is deprecated â€” use Nodemailer with OAuth2 for modern email handling.
  • No need to manage passwords manually; BTP destinations handle tokens securely.
  • Integrate HTML mail templates for clear and professional messages.
  • Ideal for CAP event-driven notifications and failure alerts.

ğŸ’¡ Conclusion

This approach gives you full control and flexibility over how emails are formatted, triggered, and secured within SAP CAP projects â€” without relying on deprecated packages. Itâ€™s lightweight, production-ready, and works seamlessly on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry environments using OAuth2-based authentication.

entry.title: LeverX Early-Stage Experience With Joule Studio in SAP Build for Access Automation
entry.content:
LeverX Applies SAP Build and Joule Studio to Streamline Role and Authorization Requests

At LeverX, we believe the next stage of enterprise software is defined by intelligent workflows â€” systems that understand context, interpret intent, and act independently.

We already used Joule Studio in one of our previous projects, where it significantly enhanced CAD data search for engineers at a manufacturing enterprise, helping them save up to four hours per week per engineer. Building on that positive experience, we used Joule Studio again to address another common challenge in large organizations: employees spending significant time requesting and managing access rights across multiple systems.

In this project, we applied Joule Studio to design an intelligent assistant that automates the process, helping employees create and submit access requests through a conversational interface while ensuring compliance with internal policies.

Exploring Intelligent Automation With Joule Studio

In our work with customers, we often see that business users spend more time on system administration tasks than on their actual work. One of the most time-consuming examples is access management â€” requesting roles, obtaining authorizations, and waiting for approvals.

This process typically involves several steps and multiple people: an employee submits a request, a support specialist verifies it, clarifies details, and then manually creates a ticket in an external system. In global organizations, this back-and-forth can take hours or even days.

Recognizing the inefficiency of this process, we analyzed how it could be reimagined with SAP Joule Studio in SAP Build. The agent builder capability in Joule Studio allows developers to create AI agents that understand user intent, access business data, and trigger actions in connected systems. For us, that meant the opportunity to transform a multi-step, manual workflow into an intelligent, conversational experience capable of handling access requests in real time.

While our project focused on a simplified scenario, we designed it with production scalability in mind. In a live enterprise setting, the same approach could connect to various SAP systems and databases, making it possible to handle complex authorization processes across departments and regions.

We envisioned a workflow where users describe their needs in natural language â€” â€œI need access to production planning data,â€ for example â€” and the agent automatically identifies the required role, gathers details, and creates a structured ticket in the companyâ€™s system. Under the hood, this seamless interaction is driven by Joule Studio, SAP AI Core, and ServiceNow working together.

By extending our experience as early adopters of Joule Studio, we wanted to explore how conversational AI could reduce repetitive work, improve compliance, and simplify user experience across enterprise systems.

Inside Our Joule-Based Solution

Our goal was to leverage the agent builder in Joule Studio for access provisioning use cases. As soon as we got access to this new functionality in Joule Studio, we started developing a prototype of our intelligent assistant called Access Agent.

The Access Agent interprets employee requests, identifies the right roles and authorizations, and automatically initiates the ticket creation process. From the userâ€™s perspective, it feels like chatting with a virtual assistant. Behind the scenes, it integrates multiple SAP BTP components into a single, cohesive workflow.

The image below illustrates the high-level architecture of our solution.

At the core is Joule Studio, which manages the conversational flow and connects to supporting services. The agent relies on SAP AI Core for reasoning and document grounding, with an S3 Object Store serving as a repository for structured data on roles and authorizations.

For this prototype scenario, the data, such as roles and permissions from SAP Digital Manufacturing, was loaded statically into the object store. In a production setup, the access database would be connected directly to the agent, allowing it to make real-time queries and retrieve up-to-date information. SAP AI Core orchestrates synchronization of the vector database and repository, including chunking and vectorization.

Each user interaction is processed through the LLM-based reasoning engine that interprets intent and invokes the right tools, whether retrieving documents, validating information, or calling an external API. For external operations, Joule Studio connects to ServiceNow, where access tickets are generated automatically once all details are collected. This ensures every request follows IT procedures without manual intervention.

We structured the development around three key layers:

  • User Interaction Layer: A conversational interface built in SAP Build where employees communicate naturally with the agent.
  • Intelligence Layer: Jouleâ€™s reasoning engine combined with the AI Core document repository containing descriptions of digital manufacturing roles and associated authorizations.
  • Integration Layer: API connection to ServiceNow for ticket generation, ensuring seamless process execution from request to confirmation.

In the image below, you can see how the Access Agent interacts with a user in a real conversation. The chatbot recognizes intent, asks clarifying questions, and guides the user toward creating a correct and complete access request â€” all within a few conversational steps.

By combining Joule Studioâ€™s AI-driven orchestration with SAP BTPâ€™s integration capabilities, we created a scalable, flexible framework for automating access management workflows â€” one that can be adapted to any organization with complex authorization structures.

What the Project Showed Us

Deploying the Access Agent showed how Joule Studio can streamline complex enterprise workflows while keeping interactions intuitive for employees. Requests for roles and authorizations that previously involved multiple steps and back-and-forth communications are now handled entirely within a conversational interface.

The agent accurately interprets user intent, guides employees through any missing information, and triggers the creation of structured access tickets automatically. This eliminates repetitive manual tasks for both employees and support teams, reducing delays and potential errors in the process.

One of the most valuable insights was how Joule Studioâ€™s AI-driven orchestration adapts to real-world scenarios without requiring rigid scripting. The agent can dynamically follow different conversation paths, handle exceptions, and connect seamlessly to external systems like ServiceNow.

Looking Ahead: The Future of Intelligent Workflows

The project again showed how Joule Studio can transform complex, manual processes into intelligent, automated workflows. By combining conversational AI with deep SAP integration, the solution simplified access management, enhanced compliance, and demonstrated clear potential for operational efficiency gains.

Looking ahead, the same approach can be expanded to production-scale solutions that connect directly to SAP authorization databases and other enterprise systems. Similar agents could also support employee onboarding, training access, or IT asset provisioning, extending intelligent automation across multiple business domains.

entry.title: Building a Smart SAP Service Desk Agent with GenKit and SAP-RPT-1
entry.content:
The Problem: In most SAP organizations, helpdesk teams manually categorize incoming ticketsâ€”assigning the right SAP module, setting priority levels, and flagging escalations. It's repetitive work that slows down response times.

The Solution: Replace this manual triage with an AI agent.

In this guide, I'll show you how to build an agent using Google GenKit and SAP-RPT-1 that automatically analyzes ticket descriptions and predicts module, priority, and escalation status. We'll explore why a simple LLM prompt isn't enoughâ€”and how a tool-based architecture makes this production-ready.

Note: This is a PoC-level implementation. Since most AI + SAP examples focus on CAP integrations, I wanted to explore a different orchestration framework. Let's see what GenKit brings to the table!

Section 1: Your Development Toolkit & Setup

Step 1. Initialize Your Node.js & TypeScript Project

# Create and enter the project directory
mkdir my-genkit-app
cd my-genkit-app

# Initialize a Node.js project
npm init -y

# Set up the source directory and main file
mkdir src
touch src/index.ts

# Install and configure TypeScript
npm install -D typescript tsx
npx tsc --init

Step 2. Install Genkit and Dependencies

# Install Genkit CLI globally
npm install -g genkit-cli

# Install local project dependencies
npm install genkit @genkit-ai/google-genai dotenv

Step 3. Configure Your API Keys

Create .env file in the root directory:

# .env
GEMINI_API_KEY=your-actual-gemini-api-key-here
SAP_RPT_API_KEY=your-actual-rpt-sandbox-api-key-here

Get Your API Keys:

  • Gemini: https://aistudio.google.com/app/apikey
  • SAP-RPT-1: https://rpt.cloud.sap/dashboard

Why GenKit? It is a lightweight, model-agnostic orchestration framework from Google. It's perfect for implementing AI-powered experiences, provides built-in observability, and works across any cloud provider.

A Quick Note on SAP-RPT-1

Before we dive in, I need to give props to whoever at SAP decided to create the RPT-1 sandbox. Seriouslyâ€”this person deserves a promotion.

Historically, the biggest barrier to experimenting with SAP's AI/ML tools has been access. Everything was locked behind enterprise licenses, complex provisioning, or buried in AI Core documentation. You'd spend more time getting credentials than actually building anything.

SAP-RPT-1 flips this. You can log in to the sandbox with SSO or email, get an API key in 1 minute, and start making predictions. 

What is SAP-RPT-1?

RPT-1 (Relational Pre-Trained Transformer) is SAP's first open-source AI model, specifically designed for tabular data prediction. Unlike general-purpose LLMs that are trained on text, RPT-1 understands structured dataâ€”think spreadsheets, database tables, CSV files.

For our use case (ticket classification), this is perfect. We have historical tickets with columns like SAP_MODULE, PRIORITY, DESCRIPTION, and ESCALATION. RPT-1 can look at patterns in this structured data and predict missing values with surprising accuracy.

The model works by:

  1. Taking your historical data as "context rows" (examples)
  2. Taking your new ticket with [PREDICT] placeholders
  3. Using transformer architecture to understand relationships between columns
  4. Returning predictions based on learned patterns

Think of it as a specialized AI that's really good at one thing: understanding how values in one column relate to values in other columns.

Why Use RPT-1 Instead of Just Gemini?

You might wonder: "Why bother with RPT-1 when Gemini can read tables too?" Valid question. Here's why:

  1. Token Efficiency: RPT-1 is designed for this. You're not burning tokens on JSON formatting and structural overhead.
  2. Specialized Training: It's trained on relational data patterns, not just general text.
  3. Consistent Predictions: For tabular data, RPT-1 gives more consistent, pattern-based results than trying to prompt-engineer a general LLM.

In practice, we'll see that Gemini + RPT-1 as a tool beats Gemini-only approaches by a factor of 36x in token efficiency while improving accuracy.

Section 2: The Journey to an Intelligent Agent (in 3 Attempts)

Quick Note on GenKit Flows

Before we start, a quick word on GenKit's core concept: Flows.

A Flow is a structured AI action with defined input/output schemas. You specify what goes in and what should come out, and GenKit handles the rest. This gives you type-safety, built-in UI for testing, and observability out of the box.

Basic structure:

export const myFlow = ai.defineFlow(
  {
    name: 'FlowName',
    inputSchema: z.object({ ... }),
    outputSchema: z.object({ ... }),
  },
  async (input) => {
    // Your logic here
    return output;
  }
);

That's all you need to know for now. Let's build.

Step 4. Attempt 1: The "Naive" LLM-Only Flow

File: src/index.ts

// src/index.ts - Attempt 1: Naive LLM-only approach
import { genkit, z } from 'genkit';
import * as dotenv from 'dotenv';
import { googleAI } from '@genkit-ai/google-genai';

dotenv.config();

const ai = genkit({
  plugins: [googleAI()],
  model: googleAI.model('gemini-2.5-flash', { temperature: 0.8 }),
});

// Input schema
const TicketInputSchema = z.object({
  description: z.string().describe('Ticket description'),
});

// Output schema
const TicketSchema = z.object({
  description: z.string(),
  sapModule: z.enum([
    "FI", "CO", "MM", "SD", "PP", "WM", "EWM", 
    "HCM", "BW", "CRM", "PM", "QM", "BASIS", 
    "SECURITY", "ADMIN"
  ]),
  priority: z.enum(["Critical", "High", "Medium", "Low"]),
  needEscalation: z.boolean(),
});

// Define the AI Flow
export const ticketPredictFlow = ai.defineFlow(
  {
    name: 'TicketPredictFlow',
    inputSchema: TicketInputSchema,
    outputSchema: TicketSchema,
  },
  async (input) => {
    const prompt = `Act as Service Desk expert.
Based on ${input.description} predict output schema fields (SAP Module, Priority).
If we need to act quickly raise escalation flag.`;

    const { output } = await ai.generate({
      prompt,
      output: { schema: TicketSchema },
    });

    if (!output) throw new Error('Failed to predict');
    return output;
  },
);

async function main() {}
main().catch(console.error);

Run it:

genkit start -- npx tsx --watch src/index.ts

GenKit comes with a built-in developer UI where you can test flows, debug tool calls, and trace execution in real-time. Navigate to localhost:4000 in your browser.

Test in Genkit UI:

{"description": "Can't login to the development system"}

Result:

  • Guessed sapModule: "BASIS"
  • Assigned priority: "Critical"

The LLM lacks business contextâ€”it doesn't know that "can't login to DEV" is typically Medium priority, not Critical.

Step 5. Attempt 2: The "Token-Hungry" LLM + History Flow

The next logical step was to provide historical context to the LLM. I generated a 1,000-ticket history.json file to include in the prompt.

But here's something that surprised me: JSON is actually not optimal for LLM prompts.

I know, I knowâ€”JSON is everywhere, it's the standard for APIs, we use it without thinking. But when you're feeding data into an LLM context window, JSON is incredibly wasteful. All those quotes, brackets, commas, and structural overhead? Those are tokens. And tokens cost money.

Think about it: {"name": "value"} uses way more tokens than just name: value. Multiply that by 1,000 rows of ticket data, and you're burning through your token budget on syntax instead of actual content.

Enter TOON (Token-Oriented Object Notation). It's a format specifically designed for LLM promptsâ€”strips away JSON's bloat while keeping data readable. The savings? 30-60% fewer tokens for the same data.

For our use case where we're feeding 1,000 historical tickets on every request, this actually matters.

First, install TOON for token optimization:

npm install @toon-format/toon

Create a sample src/history.json file:

[
  {
    "TICKET_ID": "TKT_001",
    "SAP_MODULE": "BASIS",
    "PRIORITY": "Medium",
    "DESCRIPTION": "Cannot login to development system",
    "ESCALATION": false
  },
  {
    "TICKET_ID": "TKT_002",
    "SAP_MODULE": "FI",
    "PRIORITY": "Critical",
    "DESCRIPTION": "Payment posting failed in production",
    "ESCALATION": true
  },
  {
    "TICKET_ID": "TKT_003",
    "SAP_MODULE": "MM",
    "PRIORITY": "Low",
    "DESCRIPTION": "Purchase order print layout issue",
    "ESCALATION": false
  }
]

File: src/index.ts (Updated)

// src/index.ts - Attempt 2: LLM + Historical Context (inefficient)
import { genkit, z } from 'genkit';
import * as dotenv from 'dotenv';
import { googleAI } from '@genkit-ai/google-genai';
import { encode } from '@toon-format/toon';
import historicalDataJson from './history.json' with { type: 'json' };

dotenv.config();

const ai = genkit({
  plugins: [googleAI()],
  model: googleAI.model('gemini-2.5-flash', { temperature: 0.8 }),
});

// Convert historical data to TOON format (saves 30-60% tokens)
const historicalDataToon = encode(historicalDataJson);

const TicketInputSchema = z.object({
  description: z.string().describe('Ticket description'),
});

const TicketSchema = z.object({
  description: z.string(),
  sapModule: z.enum([
    "FI", "CO", "MM", "SD", "PP", "WM", "EWM", 
    "HCM", "BW", "CRM", "PM", "QM", "BASIS", 
    "SECURITY", "ADMIN"
  ]),
  priority: z.enum(["Critical", "High", "Medium", "Low"]),
  needEscalation: z.boolean(),
});

export const ticketPredictFlowWithHistory = ai.defineFlow(
  {
    name: 'TicketPredictFlowWithHistory',
    inputSchema: TicketInputSchema,
    outputSchema: TicketSchema,
  },
  async (input) => {
    const prompt = `Act as Service Desk expert.
    
Historical ticket data (TOON format):
${historicalDataToon}

Based on the historical patterns above and this new ticket description: "${input.description}"
Predict the SAP Module, Priority, and whether escalation is needed.`;

    const { output } = await ai.generate({
      prompt,
      output: { schema: TicketSchema },
    });

    if (!output) throw new Error('Failed to predict');
    return output;
  },
);

async function main() {}
main().catch(console.error);

Result:

â±ï¸  Time: 12.72 seconds
ğŸª™ Tokens: 22,993 input tokens

Even with TOON optimization, this approach proved to be highly inefficient. Feeding 1,000 tickets to the LLM on every request is fundamentally the wrong architectureâ€”no amount of token optimization can fix that. It's slow, expensive, and doesn't scale.

Section 3: The "Right Way" â€” LLM as Orchestrator, SAP-RPT-1 as Tool

After the token disaster in Attempt 2, I had to rethink the architecture. The problem wasn't the promptâ€”it was the fundamental approach.

The Key Insight: Separation of Concerns

Instead of making the LLM do everything (understanding context + making predictions), what if we split responsibilities?

  • Gemini (LLM): Acts as the orchestratorâ€”understands the user's request, decides what needs to happen, formats the final response
  • SAP-RPT-1: Acts as the specialist toolâ€”handles the actual prediction based on historical patterns

This is analogous to how you'd structure a real team. You don't ask a senior architect to also manually check every ticket priority. The architect decides "we need a priority prediction for this ticket," then delegates to a specialist who has the historical knowledge.

How SAP-RPT-1 API Actually Works

RPT-1 is designed specifically for this pattern. Here's the mental model:

You send a POST request to https://rpt.cloud.sap/api/predict with a body containing:

  1. Context Rows: Your complete historical data (all 1,000 tickets with known values)
  2. Query Row: Your new ticket, but with [PREDICT] placeholders for fields you want the model to fill in

Example query row:

{
  "TICKET_ID": "TKT_NEW",
  "SAP_MODULE": "[PREDICT]",     // â† RPT-1 will predict this
  "PRIORITY": "[PREDICT]",        // â† RPT-1 will predict this
  "DESCRIPTION": "Can't login",   // â† We provide this
  "ESCALATION": "[PREDICT]"       // â† RPT-1 will predict this
}

The model looks at patterns in your context rows and predicts the missing values. It's like asking: "Given all these examples where Description X correlated with Module Y and Priority Z, what should the values be for this new description?"

Why This Architecture Wins

Compare the two approaches:

Attempt 2 (Bad):

User Request â†’ LLM with 1,000 tickets in prompt â†’ Prediction
              â†‘
        (22,993 tokens, 12.7s, $$$)

Attempt 3 (Good):

User Request â†’ LLM decides: "I need a prediction"
            â†’ LLM calls RPT-1 tool (sends 1,000 tickets to specialized API)
            â†’ RPT-1 returns prediction
            â†’ LLM formats response
              â†‘
        (639 tokens, 9.3s, $)

The historical data never enters the LLM's context window. It goes directly to the specialized prediction model that was built for this exact job.

GenKit's Role: Tools

GenKit makes this pattern easy through its "Tools" concept. A tool is just a function that:

  1. Has a defined input/output schema
  2. Can be called by the LLM during generation
  3. Returns structured data back to the LLM

When you give the LLM access to tools, it automatically decides when to use them based on the prompt. You'll see this in the GenKit UI traceâ€”the LLM literally "thinks": "I need to predict ticket properties, I should call the predictTicket tool."

This is the magic of agentic AI: the LLM becomes a coordinator, not a do-everything oracle.

How to Build the SAP-RPT-1 Tool

Now let's implement this. We'll create a GenKit tool that wraps the RPT-1 API call:

File: src/index.ts (Final Version)

// src/index.ts - Final: LLM Orchestrator + SAP-RPT-1 Tool
import { googleAI } from '@genkit-ai/google-genai';
import { genkit, z } from 'genkit';
import * as dotenv from 'dotenv';

dotenv.config();

const ai = genkit({
  plugins: [googleAI()],
  model: googleAI.model('gemini-2.5-flash', {
    temperature: 0.8,
  }),
});

// ===== SCHEMAS =====
const TicketInputSchema = z.object({
  description: z.string().describe('Ticket description')
});

const TicketSchema = z.object({
  description: z.string(),
  sapModule: z.enum([
    "FI", "CO", "MM", "SD", "PP", "WM", "EWM", 
    "HCM", "BW", "CRM", "PM", "QM", "BASIS", 
    "SECURITY", "ADMIN"
  ]),
  priority: z.enum(["Critical", "High", "Medium", "Low"]),
  needEscalation: z.boolean()
});

// ===== SAP-RPT-1 TOOL =====
export const predictTicketWithSAPRPT1 = ai.defineTool({
  name: 'predictTicket',
  description: 'Predicts SAP service ticket properties using SAP-RPT-1 AI model',
  inputSchema: TicketInputSchema,
  outputSchema: TicketSchema
}, async (input) => {
  try {
    // Load historical data (in production, this could come from a database)
    const historicalDataJson = (await import('./history.json', {
      with: { type: 'json' }
    })).default;

    // Create prediction row with [PREDICT] markers
    const predictionTicket = {
      TICKET_ID: "TKT_PREDICT",
      SAP_MODULE: "[PREDICT]",
      PRIORITY: "[PREDICT]",
      DESCRIPTION: input.description,
      ESCALATION: "[PREDICT]",
    };

    // Build request: historical context + new ticket
    const body = {
      rows: [...historicalDataJson, predictionTicket],
      index_column: "TICKET_ID",
    };

    // Call SAP-RPT-1 API
    const response = await fetch('https://rpt.cloud.sap/api/predict', {
      method: 'POST',
      headers: {
        'Content-Type': 'application/json',
        'Authorization': `Bearer ${process.env.SAP_RPT_API_KEY}`,
      },
      body: JSON.stringify(body)
    });

    if (!response.ok) {
      throw new Error(`SAP-RPT API error: ${response.status} ${response.statusText}`);
    }

    const data = await response.json();
    const prediction = data.prediction.predictions[0];

    // Map RPT-1 response to our schema
    return {
      description: input.description,
      sapModule: prediction.SAP_MODULE[0].prediction,
      priority: prediction.PRIORITY[0].prediction,
      needEscalation: prediction.ESCALATION[0].prediction === "1.0" ? true : false
    };

  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error calling SAP-RPT API:', error);
    throw new Error(`Failed to get prediction from SAP-RPT: ${error instanceof Error ? error.message : 'Unknown error'}`);
  }
});

// ===== MAIN AGENT FLOW =====
export const serviceTicketAgent = ai.defineFlow(
  {
    name: 'ServiceTicketAgent',
    inputSchema: TicketInputSchema,
    outputSchema: TicketSchema,
  },
  async (input) => {
    const prompt = `Act as Service Desk expert. Analyze ticket description: ${input.description}.
    
Predict and return JSON with:
- SAP Module (FI, CO, MM, SD, etc.)
- Priority (Critical, High, Medium, Low)
- requiresEscalation: true if downtime, data loss, security risk, or critical response needed

Use historical patterns for consistent routing decisions.`;

    // Genkit automatically decides when to call the tool
    const { output } = await ai.generate({
      prompt,
      output: { schema: TicketSchema },
      tools: [predictTicketWithSAPRPT1]
    });

    if (!output) throw new Error('Failed to predict');
    return output;
  },
);


async function main() {

}

main().catch(console.error);

Complete File Structure

my-genkit-app/
â”œâ”€â”€ src/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ index.ts          # Main code
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ history.json      # Historical tickets
â”œâ”€â”€ .env                  # API keys (don't commit!)
â”œâ”€â”€ .gitignore           # Add .env here
â”œâ”€â”€ package.json
â””â”€â”€ tsconfig.json

Results Comparison

Attempt Time Input Tokens Cost

1: Naive LLM~3s150
2: LLM + History12.7s22,993
3: LLM + RPT-1 Tool9.3s639

Winner: Attempt 3 - 36x more token-efficient than Attempt 2

When This Approach Makes Sense

Use This Architecture When:

  • You have historical tickets for training context
  • Historical data have good quality
  • You need consistent, explainable predictions
  • Token costs matter (high volume environments)

Don't Use This For:

  • One-off tickets without historical patterns
  • Unclear or constantly changing categories
  • Simple keyword-based routing (regex is cheaper!)

Useful Links

  • SAP-RPT-1 Sandbox: https://rpt.cloud.sap/dashboard
  • SAP-RPT-1 GitHub: https://github.com/SAP-samples/sap-rpt-1-oss
  • SAP-RPT-1 Product Page: https://www.sap.com/products/artificial-intelligence/sap-rpt.html
  • GenKit Documentation: https://firebase.google.com/docs/genkit

Found this helpful? Share your thoughts in the comments or connect with me to discuss AI integration.

entry.title: Certified Excellence: How Cognizant Sets the Benchmark for Driving Real SAP Transformation
entry.content:
Our longstanding partner Cognizant sheds light on how it is redefining SAP services for a cloud-first, AI-powered world.

In this interview, Sivakumar Varadananjayan, Assistant Vice President and Delivery Head â€“ SAP Cloud & SAP GGM Product and Resources (Global Growth Market) at Cognizant Technology Solutions, shares insights about Cognizant's Path from ERP to AI-Powered, Industry-Focused Innovation. As the leader of Cognizantâ€™s SAP Certification initiative and its Validation Partner status, Sivakumar also shares his perspective on Cognizantâ€™s renewed global certifications, the evolution of their SAP certification journey, and how they plan to further expand their SAP competencies to support customers. The conversation was conducted during Cognizantâ€™s SAP Certification process, together with Christoph Andre, SAP Auditor and Partner Manager, who led the audit at Cognizant, and Hossam Saad, SAP Partner Manager and Cognizantâ€™s main point of contact.

Sivakumar outlines how they have evolved from traditional ERP implementations to a transformation model centered on automation, intelligence, and industry specificity. He also discusses their role as a RISE with SAP Validated Partner, its commitment to SAP Best Practices, and how cloud migrations are accelerated through clean-core principles and end-to-end governance. With renewed global SAP certifications, expanded security capabilities, and deep DevOps integration, Cognizant positions itself as a pioneer in secure, future-ready SAP transformation. Looking ahead, Sivakumar shares how continued investment in talent, co-innovation, and industry-focused solutions will shape the next chapter of intelligent enterprise modernization.

 

Christoph: Cognizant is globally known for providing SAP-related services. How have you been adapting your services to ever-changing customer needs and technology innovations?

Sivakumar: Adaptability is at the heart of Cognizantâ€™s SAP strategy. Over the past decade, weâ€™ve transitioned from traditional ERP implementations to cloud-first, AI-enabled, and automation-driven models. Our approach focuses on three pillars:

  • Cloud Enablement: We leverage SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) to deliver scalable, resilient architectures that support rapid innovation and business agility.
  • Intelligent Automation: Through SAP Business AI, Joule Agents, and Cognizantâ€™s Automation Fabric, we integrate robotic process automation and generative AI into SAP workflows, reducing manual effort and improving accuracy.
  • Customer-Centric Design: We co-innovate with clients using SAPâ€™s cloud solutions and industry accelerators, ensuring transformation aligns with their business priorities and delivers measurable outcomes.

Innovation is embedded in every stage â€“ from RISE with SAP S/4HANA Conversions to AI-powered solutions like SAP-Certified Case Management AI Agent for SAP and Finance4UÂ® for industry-specific needs. These capabilities enable real-time insights, predictive analytics, and continuous modernization, helping clients thrive in a rapidly changing digital economy.

 

Christoph: Cognizant positions itself as a pioneer in leveraging SAP Business Suite, cloud ERP, and Business AI. How do you tailor your SAP services to address industry-specific challenges, and what role does innovation play?

Sivakumar: Cognizant tailors its SAP services through a deep industry-in-context approach - combining process expertise, data intelligence, and AI-driven automation to address the unique challenges of each sector. Our strategy integrates SAP Business Suite, cloud ERP, and Business AI with domain accelerators, industry templates, and pre-built integration frameworks that shorten time-to-value and enhance business agility.

Innovation is embedded in every stage - from co-innovation with SAP and hyperscale cloud platforms to leveraging SAP Business AI, developing digital twins, and advanced analytics for continuous transformation. This ensures that clients donâ€™t just modernize their ERP landscape but also unlock new business models, improve decision velocity, and stay future-ready in an AI-enabled economy.

A strong example of this innovation-led, industry-tailored approach is reflected in Cognizantâ€™s Utegration portfolio for utilities and energy enterprises:

  • Finance4UÂ® Extended Asset Accounting: Enhances SAP property accounting with regulatory-compliant, utility-specific asset management capabilities.
  • Finance4UÂ® Regulatory Accounting and Reporting: Streamlines regulated financial reporting, improving data accuracy and audit readiness.
  • Utility4Uâ„¢: A RISE with SAP-based cloud accelerator that modernizes and simplifies the utility ERP landscape while embedding industry best practices.
  • MeterData4UÂ®: Unlocks the value of Advanced Metering Infrastructure (AMI) by integrating and operationalizing meter data within SAP environments.

Together, these offerings demonstrate how Cognizant combines deep domain experience with SAP innovation to deliver measurable outcomes across industries - from operational efficiency to intelligent, data-driven growth.

 

Hossam: As a â€œRISE with SAP Validated Partner,â€ what has been your experience in leading SAP customersâ€™ migration to cloud? How are your services modeled around SAP Best Practices?

Sivakumar: As a RISE with SAP Validated Partner, our experience in leading SAP customersâ€™ migration to the cloud has been extensive and transformative. We have successfully delivered large-scale migrations for global enterprises using SAPâ€™s validated methodology, ensuring predictable timelines, reduced risks, and accelerated time-to-value. Our approach emphasizes clean core principles with embedded quality gates, supported by SAP Cloud ALM for governance and compliance.

Our services are modelled around SAP Best Practices, integrating SAPâ€™s ecosystem tools such as Cloud ALM, LeanIX, Signavio, Business Technology Platform (BTP), Joule, and Tricentis Test Automation. This toolchain enables automation, collaboration, and robust governance throughout the migration journey. Additionally, all key roles - Project Managers, Architects, Developers, and Consultants - are SAP-certified and trained on the latest cloud and AI innovations, ensuring customers are positioned for continuous innovation post-migration.

Finally, we focus on delivering customer-centric outcomes by accelerating cloud transformation with minimal disruption and ensuring smooth migration from ECC or on-premise systems to SAP S/4HANA Cloud. By leveraging SAP Best Practices and validated frameworks, we provide transparent, milestone-driven projects that reduce risk and deliver predictable results. Our engagements consistently achieve high satisfaction scores, reflecting our commitment to quality, innovation, and long-term customer success.

 

Christoph: Cognizant recently renewed global certifications for SAP Business Suite and SAP S/4HANA services and achieved its first global certification for SAP security operations. How do your competencies in DevOps, Security, and Business AI add value?

Sivakumar: Cognizantâ€™s renewed global certifications for SAP Business Suite and SAP S/4HANA services, along with its first global certification for SAP Security Operations, reinforce our ability to deliver secure, agile, and intelligent SAP transformations. These credentials validate our expertise in modernizing SAP landscapes while ensuring compliance and resilience for mission-critical environments.

Our DevOps competency accelerates SAP delivery through automated CI/CD pipelines, enabling rapid release cycles, improved quality, and seamless integration with RISE with SAP and cloud platforms. In parallel, our Security Operations capability provides proactive threat management, robust identity governance, and real-time monitoring - critical for industries with stringent regulatory requirements. Internally, Cognizant leverages a DevOps for a Unified Competency Management model across SAP competencies to bring people, process, and knowledge together around the work we do.

Finally, Business AI brings intelligence into SAP workflows by embedding predictive analytics, generative AI, and automation. This drives faster decision-making, reduces manual effort, and unlocks new business models across sectors. Together, these strengths position Cognizant as a trusted partner for enterprises seeking secure, automated, and AI-powered SAP transformations.

 

Hossam: How has your SAP certification journey evolved - from your first global certification in 2011 to today? What motivated you initially, and how has your approach changed?

Sivakumar: As you have rightly pointed out, Cognizantâ€™s SAP global certification journey began in 2011, when we became one of the earliest partners to achieve SAP Cloud Certification. At that time, our motivation was clear: to build client confidence, demonstrate market leadership, and align with our vision of driving enterprise modernization through cloud-first strategies. This milestone positioned us ahead of industry trends and validated our ability to deliver secure, scalable SAP solutions.

Since then, our approach has evolved from meeting compliance standards to driving continuous innovation. Today, certifications are part of a broader strategy focused on SAP S/4HANA, SAP BTP, and RISE with SAP, integrating AI, automation, and sustainability into transformation programs. Weâ€™ve expanded from core ERP to end-to-end digital solutions, strengthened partnerships with SAP and hyperscale cloud providers, and invested heavily in talent development through role-based certifications. For us, certification is no longer a one-time achievement - itâ€™s a continuous journey to deliver measurable business outcomes and stay ahead of client needs.

 

Hossam: Looking ahead, how do you plan to grow your SAP competency and services to support customers?

Sivakumar: Cognizant plans to deepen its SAP competency by focusing on next-generation technologies such as SAP Business AI and industry-specific solutions developed and integrated leveraging SAP BTP. We are investing in advanced capabilities around RISE with SAP, SAP BTP, and SAP S/4HANA transformations, ensuring clients can accelerate their cloud journeys with agility and resilience. Our strategy includes embedding AI-driven automation, predictive analytics, and sustainability frameworks into SAP landscapes, enabling customers to unlock new business models and achieve measurable outcomes. These innovations will be supported by strong partnerships with SAP and hyperscale cloud providers to deliver integrated, multi-cloud architectures tailored to client needs.

entry.title: SAP AIDevCon 2025: A Day That Redefined AI Innovation

What an absolute triumph yesterday was! The SAP AIDevCon 2025 event on November 8th wasn't just another conference; it was a powerful convergence of ideas, talent, and technology that truly demonstrated the revolutionary potential of Business AI.

The air in the venue was charged with incredible energy and vibrancy. We saw over 50+ passionate participants from more than 26+ diverse corporates and 3 key Indian universities come together. The goal was simple but profound: to not just talk about AI, but to build it.

Igniting Innovation: The Hands-on Experience

The day kicked off with invaluable networkingâ€”the kind that sparks future projectsâ€”followed by an inspiring keynote address from our VP, Head of APAC. This set the stage for the true excitement: the hands-on experience.

Our participants didn't just attend sessions; they became builders. They immersed themselves in cutting-edge SAP BTP AI services, specifically using:

  • SAP Build for powerful low-code process automation.

  • Document AI to intelligently process unstructured business documents.

  • Translation Hub to instantly break down language barriers in applications.

The highlight was the intensive hackathon. Our audience, a perfect blend of industry experts and bright university students, worked in fierce yet collaborative teams. The atmosphere was one of positive vibes and shared goals, where they had to train, exhibit, and deliver industry-ready prototypes.

Breakthrough Prototypes: Solving Real Problems

The solutions developed were not academic exercisesâ€”they were direct answers to critical business challenges. The teams built phenomenal prototypes that showcased the speed and scale possible with SAP BTP AI, focusing on real-world impact:

  1. Dispute Management: Creating smart solutions to automate and accelerate complex financial and operational dispute resolution.

  2. Piracy Protection: Leveraging AI to build robust, automated systems for safeguarding digital assets and intellectual property.

  3. Wellbeing: Developing AI-driven applications to enhance employee and user well-being through proactive insights and personalised support.

This entire day was a masterclass in learning, teamwork, and execution, all driven by the powerful capabilities of SAP Business Technology Platform.

Gratitude for Our Ecosystem of Heroes

A monumental event like this is only possible because of a dedicated community. A huge and sincere thank you goes out to:

  • Our incredible mentors and volunteers whose guidance transformed ideas into working code.

  • All the brilliant participants for bringing their enthusiasm and skill.

  • The SAP Leadership for championing the vision of an AI-first future.

  • The unsung heroes in IT, Security, and Admin, and each and every hero behind the scenes, whose seamless work made the entire event feel effortless.

What's Next? A Teaser!

The energy and innovation we witnessed at SAP AIDevCon 2025 proved one thing: the appetite for building intelligent, transformative solutions is immense.

This event was a resounding success, and we're already hard at work planning something even bigger and better. Stay tuned, because we are preparing to launch the next, even more exciting, version of AIDevCon very soon!

Keep learning, keep building, and we look forward to welcoming you back to the innovation floor.
